Critics said that the study you did in 2004 had too wide a confidence interval.
First of all, what does that mean?
And second of all, how did you address it in going back and doing more research?
A confidence interval is a, are really two numbers, a low number and a high number, and between those two we would be 95 percent confident that the true number is in that figure.
And the figure that we choose to represent our findings, in this case the 654,000, represents statistically the most likely number.
And the chance of a likely number being less or more drops off fairly quickly as you move to either side of that number.
Now one of the things that will reduce confidence intervals is to increase sample size, and we did increase the sample size substantially this time.
So instead of having 900 households, we had 1,849 households.
So it was a much bigger sample size.
However, when you increase the sample size, you also increase the risk to your interviewers.
So we have to do a trade off here about how much risk we want to expose our interviewers to for the benefit of having narrower confidence intervals.
And so that's an ethical as well as a practical decision.
And you would think that the greatest danger to your interviewers would be in many of the places where the incidence of death is the highest.
And in fact, interviewers in Iraq have been killed and have been injured before, and I'm very happy to say that none of that happened to any of our interviewers.
How do you respond when you hear the president say, as we just heard that piece of tape a moment ago, that your methods have been discredited, your report not credible?

Well, we are comfortable with the methods, we are comfortable with our results, and I think we are comfortable with the principle message, which we want to come out of this, and that is that the population caught up in conflict is bearing a very serious consequence to this conflict.

And with these numbers, we hope that it will stimulate discussion of how to improve the protection of people in conflict situations not only in Iraq right now, but in the conflicts that will come in the future.
We in this country have an excellent method for monitoring what happens to our soldiers.

But at the same time, we need to be aware of what happens to people caught up in the conflict who really have no one to look to for protection, and that's a responsibility of the international community.
And developing methods to protect them starts with good data, and that's where we want to start.
